captions.text:
Once upon a time in the mystical land of Tamriel,
the benevolent ruler of Cyrodil, Emperor Uriel

Septim VII, is secretly usurped and banished
to Oblivion by none other than Jafar, er,

I mean "Jagar," the king's most trusted advisor.
However, our hero is able to oust Jagar by

traipsing throughout all the provinces of
Tamriel and gathering pieces of the mystical

MacGuffin Staff, which is never heard about
or seen again despite all of the BS.

Years later, a new hero is hired by Uriel
Septim to sail to Daggerfall and investigate

numerous mysterious goings-on. Once arrived,
Sir-or-Madam Hero discovers a plot to reactivate

a humongous fancy mecha. After deciding who
gets control over Optimus, in the end it turns

out all possible endings are canon, except
where the robot goes bezerk and Goomba-stomps
the whole of Tamriel.

A few more years later, a disease known as
The Blight is sweeping across the North-Eastern

province of Morrowind. Papa Uriel, showing
the same kind of ingenious logic he used when

he appointed his grand vizier, chooses to
send a convicted criminal to solve the problem.

Shockingly enough though, the criminal-hero
manages to stop The Blight Kratos-style by
killing a local evil god. High fives all around!

Funnily enough, this wouldn't be the last
time someone is released from prison to save

the day, but this time ol' Uriel is assassinated
by a cult with a name pulled straight from

the emo poetry of a highschool girl. Fortunately,
our hero, with the aid of Martin Septim, is

able to stop the invasion and save Tamriel
from certain ruination.

Of course, now it's time for the new Elder
Scrolls and it's the doomiest one yet! Alduin,

the Nordic aspect of Akatosh (the dragon-god
of time), has returned to destroy the current

riffraff and begin a new dragony filled world.
However, our latest hero is the last of the

Dragonborn, a person born with the "soul of
a dragon" who might be able to save the day

by defeating the god of time and his army
of gigantic, evil dark dragon spirits who

eat entire towns much larger than you on a
regular basis.
Have fun.

Oh and if you're wondering why the Elder Scrolls
are significant... they kind of aren't.

title: LORE - The Elder Scrolls Lore in a Minute!

comments.text:
As I remember, in the first elder scrolls game, you are the captain of the 
guard and was thrown in prison by the fake king because you posed a threat 
to his scheming. So you start out in prison, and break free. In Morrowind, 
you are an orphan with unknown parents and was in prison for unknown 
reasons and is sent to Morrowind because the emperor thinks you might be 
the Nevarine. In Oblivion, you are in prison for unknown reasons and are 
set free because the emperor's secret escape route happened to be in your 
cell as he was fleeing assassins. In Skyrim, you were at the wrong place at 
the wrong time and was captured with some rebels and was sentenced to be 
executed with them because they thought you might be a rebel and a dragon 
attacks and you manage to escape. So the question is, in the second game, 
did you start the game as a prisoner like you started all the other games?﻿

doing it.  He only made you(the LDB) because Alduin wasn't obeying his 
rules and trying to end the world earlier than it was supposed to.

comments.text:
Elder Scrolls are actually extremely important in the lore of Elder 
Scrolls, not exactly for the games though. The lore behind the Elder 
Scrolls is basically that they have told of every major event that is 
supposed to happen, written by Akatosh himself. Very few people can read 
the Elder Scrolls, but those who do are able to prophesize events hundreds 
of years in advance. The Elder Scrolls are the bridge between the knowledge 
of the Gods to the mortals on Nirn, and play a huge role in what transpire.﻿

comments.text:
It goes something like this: after activation of the Anumidium (or Numidium 
in this case) time broke, as there were different realities, where all 
events happened but in a different manner or outcome, followed a different 
path or didn't happen at all (Numidium and Tamriel gettin' r3kt), and after 
some time all time-streams were brought back together into a one, singular 
stream of events, but this caused all events happen at once and being real 
at the same time. Such an event is called the Dragon Break.

For simplicity: imagine a river that's breaking into different flows. To 
each of these flows you pour a different liquid and some you dry out, and 
at some point they all get back together forming a main stream with the mix 
of all the liquids at the same time.

Now all I need to do, is to figure out how to get women using this stuff.

comments.author: Sap Licker

comments.text:
The Book of the Dragonborn
by Prior Emelene Madrine
Order of Talos
Weynon Priory
A treatise on the Dragonborn
Year 360 of the Third Era, Twenty-First of the Reign of His Majesty 
Pelagius IV
Many people have heard the term "Dragonborn" - we are of course ruled by 
the "Dragonborn Emperors" - but the true meaning of the term is not 
commonly understood. For those of us in the Order of Talos, this is a 
subject near and dear to our hearts, and in this book I will attempt to 
illuminate the history and significance of those known as Dragonborn down 
through the ages.
Most scholars agree that the term was first used in connection with the 
Covenant of Akatosh, when the blessed St. Alessia was given the Amulet of 
Kings and the Dragonfires in the Temple of the One were first lit. 
"Akatosh, looking with pity upon the plight of men, drew precious blood 
from his own heart, and blessed St. Alessia with this blood of Dragons, and 
made a Covenant that so long as Alessia's generations were true to the 
dragon blood, Akatosh would endeavor to seal tight the Gates of Oblivion, 
and to deny the armies of daedra and undead to their enemies, the 
Daedra-loving Ayleids." Those blessed by Akatosh with "the dragon blood" 
became known more simply as Dragonborn.
The connection with the rulers of the Empire was thus there from the 
beginning - only those of the dragon blood were able to wear the Amulet of 
Kings and light the Dragonfires. All the legitimate rulers of the Empire 
have been Dragonborn - the Emperors and Empresses of the first Cyrodilic 
Empire founded by Alessia; Reman Cyrodiil and his heirs; and of course 
Tiber Septim and his heirs, down to our current Emperor, His Majesty 
Pelagius Septim IV.
Because of this connection with the Emperors, however, the other 
significance of the Dragonborn has been obscured and largely forgotten by 
all but scholars and those of us dedicated to the service of the blessed 
Talos, Who Was Tiber Septim. Very few realize that being Dragonborn is not 
a simple matter of heredity - being the blessing of Akatosh Himself, it is 
beyond our understanding exactly how and why it is bestowed. Those who 
become Emperor and light the Dragonfires are surely Dragonborn - the proof 
is in the wearing of the Amulet and the lighting of the Fires. But were 
they Dragonborn and thus able to do these things - or was the doing the 
sign of the blessing of Akatosh descending upon them? All that we can say 
is that it is both, and neither - a divine mystery.
The line of Septims have all been Dragonborn, of course, which is one 
reason the simplistic notion of it being hereditary has become so 
commonplace. But we know for certain that the early Cyrodilic rulers were 
not all related. There is also no evidence that Reman Cyrodiil was 
descended from Alessia, although there are many legends that would make it 
so, most of them dating from the time of Reman and likely attempts to 
legitimize his rule
comments.author: oblivion modder

comments.text:
Only dragonborns with the dragon souls can absorb the souls of dragons. 
Dragonborns with just the blood cannot do this. Alduin is an aspect of 
Aka-tusk. All of these aspects are time gods. Alduin represents the end of 
time. Other aspects include Alkosh and Auri-El.
comments.author: Sap Licker

comments.text:
Alduin said himself that he is the first born of Akatosh. Would you say you 
were the first born of somebody you're not? What would be the point?! And 
the dragonborn has the blood of akatosh, akatosh promised the early people 
of tamriel that if they stay true to the dragon blood, he would keep the 
gates of oblivion closed. The dragonborn is able to kill dragons and take 
their soul, and knowledge of the thu'um, but this is similar to the soul 
capture spell/enchantment where a soul is put in a soul gem(though not 
actually the same), it takes the soul, the soul is stored, and the soul is 
used. The dragonborn does not actually have the soul of a dragon in 
him/herself. Perhaps you should revisit the elder scrolls V and look for 
whatever your misinformation is based on.
comments.author: insaneminecraftninja

comments.text:
The Last Dragonborn has both the blood and soul of a dragon. Some 
dragonborns only have the blood, some only have the soul and some have 
both. Alduin is not the son of Akatosh. He is an aspect of Aka-tusk.
comments.author: Sap Licker

comments.author: video gamerx7

comments.text:
+Sothas Very informative explanation, but I when you say "He (Aka) is the 
physical manifestation of Anu within the Aurbis, While Anui-El is the 
Aurbical manifestation of Anu within the Dream." what exactly is the 
"dream" in relation to the Aurbis?
comments.author: Kronic Shade

comments.text:
Alright, let me help. So Akatosh, Auri-El, Alduin, Alkosh, Tosh-Raka, and 
other gods of Time, are all shards of a greater being called Aka, or 
sometimes Aka-Tusk. Aka is on the same sub-gradient level as Lorkhan, and 
has a similar shattering of being (but didn't die). He is the physical 
manifestation of Anu within the Aurbis, While Anui-El is the Aurbical 
manifestation of Anu within the Dream. Auri-El was the first of the shards, 
representing the beginning of time. Alduin was the next, representing the 
end of time. Some think that Alkosh represents the continuity of time and 
is responsible to repairing it when it goes to pot, with the assistance of 
the Jill. Tosh-Raka is the future. Akatosh is the aspect of time that 
represents the present.So remember how I I said Auri-El was the first? 
Well.... Akatosh was also the first because the Marukhati Selectives dances 
of a Tower and jacked up the Time gods. Akatosh is a mix of Lorkhan (or 
Shor) and Auri-El. The Selectives attempted to remove Auri-El from him. 
This may or may not have been successful and likely make Akatosh as he is 
today, very Padomaic time god. The Selectives sort of retconned the gods 
(because Dawn magic) and poof, we're where we're at today. Dragons are 
lesser time spirits. Smaller pieces of the Aka oversoul. 

If Aka is a bucket of water, it spilled and the time gods are like large 
puddles where most of the water came puddled together. Small drops of water 
scattered around are like the dovah and jill. 

In short, Alduin, Akatosh, Auri-El, Alkosh, and Tosh-Raka (I'm probably 
forgetting one) are all on the "same level" as they are of the same 
sub-gradient within the dream. Akatosh was retconned into first, thus 
Alduin is the first of Akatosh. He explains it this way because mortals are 
stupid and probably couldn't truly comprehend exactly how he fits into the 
whole thing. 

Alduin's a pretty special and unique being in the Aurbis.
comments.author: Sothas

comments.author: Kronic Shade

comments.text:
Its super duoer unlikely that alduin is akatosh as alduin inhabits an area 
much different to akatoshes "plane" (akatosh is aedra and so also has a 
plain much like daedric beings). Killing an aedra means completely 
destroying their planes as they are one, oblivion and mehrunes. As such, as 
the dragonborn vanquishes Alduin without destroyin sovenrgarde, it seems 
unlikely that Alduin is aedric and thus, that he his Akatosh. Furthermore, 
the timeline consistency doesnt reallly add up, i mean how long exactly was 
"akatosh" flying around as Alduin after he helped create mundus before we 
was banished what ever period of time into the future, plus how was he able 
to assist in the events of Oblivion if he was banished to a point after 
that event 2000 odd years ago?

comments.author: Alex Holland

comments.text:
I don't agree that the scrolls aren't significant in context of the games, 
but they could play a bigger role than serving as convenient help for 
quests. Frankly, I'm surprised more villains don't try to just steal all 
the scrolls and somehow attain ultimate knowledge. If dragons are coming 
back now, surely a person or daedra who can survive seeing the scrolls and 
harness their power is possible. They should work on an antagonist who has 
the ability to absorb the wisdom contained within each scroll upon reading 
it (similar to dragonborn, I know), which would eventually make him smart 
and powerful enough that no one could win by fighting head on. He/she/it 
could then raise an empire controlled through the combined accumulated 
wisdom of the scrolls, creating a nearly perfect strategic defense, 
military, manipulation of other provinces' leaders, pretty much total 
political rear ending. It would then be up to the hero, born a few decades 
later, to defeat this empire not by simply attacking it but by finding 
ancient magic to take away the power of each scroll the villain has read 
and return it to the scrolls where they are hidden. This would have to be 
done before the villain finds the final scrolls that his/her/its army is 
seeking across Tamriel, gaining enough power to become a god. Once the 
villain's mind and power have been weakened to where a direct attack is 
effective, you can have an all out battle of scroll vs scroll mayhem. After 
that, use your remaining power to just walk through the spaces between 
reality and travel back to before the scrolls were scattered across 
Tamriel, sending them all to a new land beyond where mortals will never 
find them... until the next game. ﻿
